segment.source: Binding to a collection of items
segment.target: Binding to a collection of items

segment.source: A common scenario is to bind to a collection of business objects.
segment.target: A common scenario is to bind to a collection of business objects.

segment.source: In C# and Visual Basic, the generic ObservableCollectionT class is a good collection choice for data binding, because it implements the INotifyPropertyChanged and INotifyCollectionChanged interfaces.
segment.target: In C# and Visual Basic, the generic ObservableCollectionT class is a good collection choice for data binding, because it implements the INotifyPropertyChanged and INotifyCollectionChanged interfaces.

segment.source: These interfaces provide change notification to bindings when items are added or removed or a property of the list itself changes.
segment.target: These interfaces provide change notification to bindings when items are added or removed or a property of the list itself changes.

segment.source: If you want your bound controls to update with changes to properties of objects in the collection, the business object should also implement INotifyPropertyChanged.
segment.target: If you want your bound controls to update with changes to properties of objects in the collection, the business object should also implement INotifyPropertyChanged.

segment.source: Adding a details view
segment.target: Adding a details view

segment.source: You can choose to display all the details of Recording objects in ListView items.
segment.target: You can choose to display all the details of Recording objects in ListView items.

segment.source: But that takes up a lot of space.
segment.target: But that takes up a lot of space.

segment.source: Instead, you can show just enough data in the item to identify it and then, when the user makes a selection, you can display all the details of the selected item in a separate piece of UI known as the details view.
segment.target: Instead, you can show just enough data in the item to identify it and then, when the user makes a selection, you can display all the details of the selected item in a separate piece of UI known as the details view.

segment.source: This arrangement is also known as a master/details view, or a list/details view.
segment.target: This arrangement is also known as a master/details view, or a list/details view.

segment.source: There are two ways to go about this.
segment.target: There are two ways to go about this.

segment.source: You can bind the details view to the SelectedItem property of the ListView.
segment.target: You can bind the details view to the SelectedItem property of the ListView.

segment.source: Or you can use a CollectionViewSource: bind both the ListView and the details view to the CollectionViewSource (which will take care of the currently-selected item for you).
segment.target: Or you can use a CollectionViewSource: bind both the ListView and the details view to the CollectionViewSource (which will take care of the currently-selected item for you).
